concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may try to create compound words from any two words, producing combinations that do not exist. They may not realise that both parts of a compound word contribute to its meaning. Some children write compound words as two separate words (e.g., 'foot ball') or attempt to split non-compound words (e.g., thinking 'carpet' is 'car' + 'pet').

concepts.description: Using correct terms: letter, word, sentence, noun, verb, adjective, etc.
concepts.teaching_guidance: Introduce grammatical terminology as specified in the National Curriculum Appendix 2 for each year group. Year 1 terms include: letter, capital letter, word, singular, plural, sentence, punctuation, full stop, question mark, exclamation mark. Year 2 adds: noun, noun phrase, statement, question, exclamation, command, compound, suffix, adjective, adverb, verb, tense (past, present), apostrophe, comma. Teach terms in context, using them when discussing reading and writing. Display terms with definitions and examples.
concepts.key_vocabulary: noun, verb, adjective, adverb, sentence, punctuation, singular, plural, tense, suffix, compound
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may learn grammatical terms as definitions without understanding how to apply them. They may confuse similar terms (e.g., noun/noun phrase, adjective/adverb). Some children can identify word classes in isolation but not within sentences. Others may resist using technical vocabulary, preferring informal descriptions.

concepts.description: Using grammatically correct English in writing
concepts.teaching_guidance: Begin raising awareness of Standard English in Year 2, focusing on common non-standard forms that children may use in speech. Address subject-verb agreement (e.g., 'we were' not 'we was'), consistent use of standard verb forms (e.g., 'I did' not 'I done', 'she went' not 'she goed'), and double negatives (e.g., 'I didn't do anything' not 'I didn't do nothing'). Approach sensitively: validate children's home language and dialect while teaching that Standard English is used in formal contexts and in writing.
concepts.key_vocabulary: Standard English, correct, grammar, writing, formal, we were, I did, she went, spoken, written
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may feel their home dialect or spoken language is 'wrong' if Standard English is presented as the only correct form. They may not understand when Standard English is required (writing and formal speech) versus when dialect is appropriate (informal speech). Some children apply Standard English rules inconsistently, particularly with irregular verb forms.

concepts.description: Attending to and understanding what others say
concepts.teaching_guidance: Develop listening skills through focused listening activities: follow multi-step instructions, identify specific sounds or words in a spoken passage, and respond to what a partner has said. Use circle time to practise attentive listening with eye contact and still bodies. Teach children to show they are listening through body language and by asking follow-up questions. Play barrier games where children must listen carefully to instructions to complete a task they cannot see.
concepts.key_vocabulary: listen, hear, pay attention, eyes on the speaker, still body, what did they say, respond
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may appear to be listening (sitting still, looking at the speaker) without actually processing what is being said. They may hear the first instruction but not subsequent ones. Some children equate listening with waiting for their turn to speak rather than genuinely attending to another person's contribution.

concepts.description: Taking appropriate turns when speaking in groups
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach explicit turn-taking strategies during class discussions and partner work. Use visual aids such as a talking stick or talking token to show whose turn it is to speak. Model waiting, listening to the speaker, and responding before making a new point. Teach children to build on what others have said: 'I agree with ___ because...', 'I think something different...' Practise in small groups before whole-class discussions so that all children have opportunities to contribute.
concepts.key_vocabulary: turn, wait, listen, your turn, my turn, speak, respond, take turns, share, one at a time
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may interrupt others because they are eager to share their idea and fear forgetting it. They may wait for their turn without listening to what is being said. Some children are reluctant to take a turn at all, particularly in whole-class settings. Others may dominate the conversation without awareness of others' need to contribute.

concepts.description: Asking questions that extend understanding
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach children to ask relevant questions that extend their understanding. Model questioning during shared reading: 'I wonder why the character did that? Let me ask a question.' Teach question starters (who, what, where, when, why, how) and practise generating questions about a topic or text. Use 'question of the day' routines and partner questioning activities. Distinguish between questions that have a single factual answer and questions that invite discussion and opinion.
concepts.key_vocabulary: question, ask, who, what, where, when, why, how, wonder, find out, I want to know
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children often make statements disguised as questions or ask questions that are not relevant to the topic. They may ask questions they already know the answer to rather than genuine enquiry questions. Some children are reluctant to ask questions because they fear appearing foolish.

concepts.description: Giving reasons for views and answers
concepts.teaching_guidance: Teach children to justify their opinions using the frame 'I think... because...' Start with simple preferences: 'Which character do you like best? Why?' Progress to justifying opinions about texts, events and ideas. Model the difference between stating an opinion ('I like this book') and justifying it ('I like this book because the pictures help me imagine the story'). Use talk partners so that all children practise justifying opinions orally before being asked to do so in front of the whole class.
concepts.key_vocabulary: because, I think, reason, why, explain, opinion, agree, disagree, evidence, justify
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children frequently state opinions without any justification. They may give circular reasons ('I like it because it's good'). Some children confuse opinions with facts, presenting subjective preferences as objective truths. Others find it difficult to disagree respectfully with a peer's opinion.

concepts.description: Taking on roles to explore characters and situations
concepts.teaching_guidance: Use drama and role-play activities to develop children's spoken language, imagination and understanding of texts. Strategies include hot-seating (interviewing a character), freeze-frame (creating still images of key moments), conscience alley (exploring a character's dilemma), and small-world play. Use role-play areas linked to the class topic or text being studied. Drama should be purposeful, developing language and understanding rather than being purely recreational. Follow up with writing in role or discussion of what was learned.
concepts.key_vocabulary: role-play, drama, character, pretend, imagine, act out, perform, hot-seat, freeze-frame
concepts.common_misconceptions: Children may see drama as 'just playing' rather than a structured learning activity. They may find it difficult to stay in character or to speak as someone other than themselves. Some children are reluctant to participate in drama activities due to shyness, requiring carefully scaffolded, low-stakes entry points such as partner work before group performance.

prerequisite_relationships.rationale: Children must understand what phonemes are before they can blend them together to read words
Children must understand what graphemes are before they can blend the sounds they represent
Knowledge of GPCs is essential for decoding unfamiliar words
Blending skill is the core mechanism for decoding words
Children must decode words many times before recognition becomes automatic
Accurate decoding is necessary before fluent reading can develop
Knowledge of consonant digraphs expands the range of words that can be decoded
Knowledge of vowel digraphs expands the range of words that can be decoded
Understanding split digraphs enables reading of words like 'make' and 'time'
Understanding syllables helps in breaking down longer words for decoding
Fluent reading frees cognitive resources for higher-level comprehension like inference
Children typically retrieve explicit information before making inferences
Broader vocabulary enables deeper comprehension and inference
Understanding story structure helps children predict what might happen next
Children must retrieve events before they can sequence them
Understanding phonemes is essential for segmenting words into sounds for spelling
Segmenting is the core skill for spelling using phonics
Knowledge of GPCs is needed to choose correct graphemes when spelling
Children must identify root words before adding suffixes
Children must identify root words before adding prefixes
Understanding suffixes includes knowing how to add -s/-es for plurals
Basic phonetic spelling develops before learning complex spelling patterns
Understanding contractions with apostrophes helps with possessive apostrophes
Secure phonetic spelling is needed before distinguishing homophones
Correct pencil grip and posture are essential for forming letters properly
Understanding letter families helps with efficient and correct letter formation
Basic letter formation must be secure before focusing on relative sizing
Letters must be correctly sized and formed before they can be joined
Letter formation skill relates to spatial awareness for word spacing
Understanding sentence boundaries is essential for composing sentences
Oral rehearsal scaffolds written sentence composition for young writers
Children must compose individual sentences before sequencing them into narratives
Understanding story structure helps with sequencing narrative sentences
Children must compose sentences before they can re-read and evaluate them
Re-reading for basic sense precedes more sophisticated evaluation
Re-reading for sense develops into proof-reading for specific errors
Basic sentence composition precedes adapting writing for different purposes
Children sequence sentences before learning to plan multi-paragraph writing
Understanding sentence boundaries is necessary for using capital letters correctly
Understanding sentence boundaries is necessary for using full stops correctly
Understanding sentence types is needed to use question marks appropriately
Understanding sentence types is needed to use exclamation marks appropriately
Using 'and' for coordination precedes using other coordinating conjunctions
Simple coordination with 'and' typically precedes subordination
Understanding nouns is necessary for expanding noun phrases
Understanding adjectives is necessary for expanding noun phrases
Understanding verbs is necessary for using tenses correctly
Basic understanding of tense precedes using progressive forms
Understanding verbs precedes understanding how adverbs modify them
Basic listening skills are necessary for effective turn-taking in discussion
Listening and understanding are prerequisites for asking relevant questions
Discussing texts develops the ability to justify opinions with evidence
Children must decode competently before they can notice and correct errors
Spelling competence is needed to identify spelling errors during proof-reading
Punctuation knowledge is needed to identify punctuation errors during proof-reading
Reading fluency relates to ability to read aloud with appropriate expression
Letter formation skill supports spelling, though they develop somewhat independently
Broader vocabulary enables richer discussion about texts
